text: I think we've learned a lot from from
this crisis and I think one of the
things is kind of what we've been
talking about that that when firms take
a lot of
risk to some extent they're taking
risk beyond what they feel themselves.
In other words, when large companies
take on
risk, then they impose risks on the rest
of the system.
And these are systemic risks. And these
systemic risks we never used to think
were really that important. But as soon
as we recognize how the financial
sector, the risks that the financial
sector takes on can impact the entire
global economy, we realize that those
risks needed to be controlled for the
social good and and reduced the systemic
risks. So we have a new push to
understand systemic risk, where it comes
from, how do you measure it, how do you
regulate it and the financial regulation
that has been discussed for uh a year in
the US and and which is is is about to
be uh uh put into place I think and
which is being discussed in Europe and
and everywhere focuses very much on
systemic risk that those are the risks
that you want to spend most of your
regulatory time worrying about. So that
leads us to regulating more
carefully the largest or the most
systemically risky companies and uh
institutions. I think we're fooling
ourselves if we think that regulators
are going to be able to outsmart the
bankers.
So the task of designing regulatory
reform is trying to make more or less
foolproof regulation. Uh and that's one
of the advantages of the systemic
uh category where you if you can decide
that some smaller number of banks or
financial institutions are the ones to
worry about then you can give them more
scrutiny and more attention. You don't
have to have rules that apply to
everybody.
Uh
and I think that you can do sort of what
the Fed has often done which is said
called leaning against the wind. In
other words, if you think that there's
too much risk being taken and that that
the financial sector is being
superheated, you can actually increase
their capital requirements at that
point. When Greenspan, who had no
appetite for regulating risk, thought
things were getting out of hand, he
coined the phrase irrational exuberance
to to cover it. But all he had was
talking points. And with this new
regulatory environment, there would be
more than talking points. There would be
things that could be done. Uh I do think
that the reason the regulators were
asleep at the switch in part was because
we have had so much success in the US
history with
deregulation. It's done valuable things
for the trucking industry, for airlines,
for
telecommunications. We've expanded
deregulation, gotten government out of
one sector after another. And I think
that the Greenspan approach and the Cox
SEC were in that tradition of let's
deregulate and see what these markets
do. And one of the things they
immediately observed is that these
markets took off. But they took off by
taking more and more risk, which it
turned out to be risks that the
taxpayers were really taking. So I think
what we've learned is that deregulation
is not as effective in the financial
sectors or at least it can't go as far
in the financial sectors as it has in
some of these other uh sectors. And so I
think while they were asleep at the
switch, I don't
think it was really just the regulators
that are asleep at the switch. I think
that they were appointed to be asleep at
the switch and that Congress
congressional oversight wanted them to
be asleep and so that it really was
across the board. It's not really just
the regulators missed it. They were
appointed to not do
anything. I think they're more
cautious. On the other hand, that was
true in 2003 also when they had they had
uh run up the internet bubble in 2000 in
1999 and then all of a sudden it blew
blew apart. So people were cautious for
a while but then they jumped on on some
other bubbles. We had an energy bubble
and then we had the the banking bubble
and those and I guess the housing
bubble. So I'm not really sure whether
Americans are going to be uh better
investors.
